raw_text:
Howard 'truanted to play snooker'
 
 Conservative leader Michael Howard has admitted he used to play truant to spend time with his school friends at a snooker hall.
 
 Mr Howard said his time at Jack's Snooker Hall in Llanelli in the 1950s had not done him "any lasting damage". But he told the Times Educational Supplement that truancy was "very bad" and said "firm action" was needed. Mr Howard also called for a return to O-levels and more classroom discipline.
 
 Mr Howard eventually left Llanelli Grammar School - and the snooker hall - to go to Cambridge University. He said: "I don't think it's done me any lasting damage. Nor has it made me a snooker world champion. "There might have been some occasions when we left early of an afternoon.
 
 "I'm just being honest. I think truancy is a very bad thing and that firm action should be taken to deal with it." Another player who has failed to win snooker's world championship - Jimmy "the Whirlwind " White - has previously admitted missing lessons, instead spending his days in smoky halls. "Tony Meo [another player] and me used to spend all of our spare time there," Mr White said, "We loved the game and the atmosphere. "School went out of the window. I went for a while and then started taking time off." Mr Howard's fellow Welshman Ray Reardon - known by his fellow professionals as "Dracula" - won the snooker world championship six times, having left school at 14 to work as a miner. And Terry Griffiths, like Mr Howard from Llanelli, won the tournament in 1979. It is not known whether the two of them ever clashed cues at Jack's.
llama3.2:1b: Michael Howard, a Conservative leader, admitted to truancing to play snooker and spend time with friends at a local hall. He said he didn't think it did him "any lasting damage" but called for more classroom discipline. Howard left school at 15 to attend Cambridge University.
llama3.2:3b: Michael Howard admitted to playing truant to spend time with friends at a snooker hall in the 1950s, calling it "very bad" and advocating for firm action against truancy. He left school for Cambridge University after leaving the hall.
gemma2:2b: Michael Howard admitted to truancy while attending a snooker hall in his youth. He now advocates for stricter disciplinary measures and traditional O-level education. Notable professional players like Jimmy White and Ray Reardon, who did not excel in academics but achieved success in snooker, provide counter examples.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Conservative politician Michael Howard admitted truancy while at snooker hall to spend time with school friends and called for stricter action against the issue.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Michael Howard admitted he truanted snooker during school years but regrets it now and calls for stricter discipline measures. He left school to pursue his passion later.
qwen2.5:3b: Conservative leader Michael Howard admitted he used to play truant to spend time at a snooker hall in Llanelli during the 1950s. While he claimed it did not harm him, he advocated for firm action against truancy and called for O-levels and better classroom discipline. Howard left school to attend Cambridge University but noted there were occasions when they would leave early in the afternoon. Other players like Jimmy "the Whirlwind" White also mentioned their time at snooker halls led them to miss lessons, although they never became world champions. Welsh professionals Ray Reardon and Terry Griffiths both won the championship despite leaving school earlier.
opencoder:1.5b: Constituting a summary, Howard 'tranted to play snooker' with Mr Howard’s remarks about truant times, his time at Jack's Snooker Hall and the negative impacts he faced on society. He also mentioned that Mr Howard left Llanelli Grammar School and returned to Cambridge University, suggesting that he was no longer a part of Llanelli. He also said he felt that firm action should be taken to deal with truancy.

deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so I need to summarize this text about Mr. Michael Howard who used to play snooker as a truant. Let me read through it carefully.

First, Howard says he played truant in snooker hall for his school friends back in the 1950s. He claims that his time there didn't cause any lasting damage, which is interesting because I know some people use truancy to keep busy. But Mr. Howard also admitted that truancy was very bad and that he needed more firm action. That makes sense; sometimes even good intentions can lead to problems.

He mentions leaving Llanelli Grammar School after school in 1958. There, he played snooker, but he eventually left for Cambridge University. He said it wasn't doing him any harm and he doesn’t think he’ll win a snooker world championship. That's quite a contrast. I wonder why people might say he didn’t win. Maybe because he was busy with truancy?

Another player, Jimmy White, who failed to win the championship, admitted missing lessons instead of going to snooker hall. He used to spend his time there and loved the game. I remember seeing some stories about him in school, maybe he was really into it.

Mr. Howard's fellow Welshman, Ray Reardon, won the world title at 14 after working as a miner. I think that's not true because when I looked up, Ray was actually a sportsman, but his career path is a bit off. Terry Griffiths from Llanelli also won in 1979, so maybe they had some interactions? But the text doesn't mention it.

So putting this all together, Howard was busy for good, which led to a lot of negative consequences. He's leaving Cambridge because he didn't do anything wrong, even though he played snooker. Other players have missed games because of this truancy thing, and some are still serious about their sports careers, like Ray Reardon.

I should make sure I capture the main points: Howard's truancy history, his actions at snooker hall, his decision to leave for university, his opinions on truancy being bad, and other players' experiences. Also, mention that he didn't win a championship but others did.
</think>

Howard 'truanted to play snooker' after playing it as a truant back in the 1950s at Llanelli Grammar School. He claims his time there didn’t cause lasting damage, yet he admits truancy was bad and urged more action. He left Cambridge University after leaving school in 1958 to study snooker at university, believing it wasn’t doing him any harm. Despite this, he doesn’t think he’ll win a championship or leave behind legacy. Other players like Jimmy White had similar experiences of missing games due to truancy, while Ray Reardon and Terry Griffiths are serious about their sports careers, with Reardon winning at 14 after mining.

**Summary:**

- Howard used snooker as a truant in the 1950s.
- He claims his time there didn’t cause harm but admitted truancy was bad.
- Howard left Cambridge for school in 1958 and stayed busy, not winning a championship.
- Jimmy White missed games due to truancy.
- Ray Reardon won snooker at 14 after mining.
- Terry Griffiths also won in 1979, but their careers differ.

Howard's story reflects negative consequences of truancy leading to long-term issues.
